name: High Scores
prompt:
# Instructions

Manage a game player's High Score list.

Your task is to build a high-score component of the classic Frogger game, one of the highest selling and most addictive games of all time, and a classic of the arcade era.
Your task is to write methods that return the highest score from the list, the last added score and the three highest scores.
# Instructions append

In this exercise, you're going to use and manipulate lists. Python lists are very versatile, and you'll find yourself using them again and again in problems both simple and complex.

- [**Data Structures (Python 3 Documentation Tutorial)**](https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/datastructures.html)
- [**Lists and Tuples in Python (Real Python)**](https://realpython.com/python-lists-tuples/)
- [**Python Lists (Google for Education)**](https://developers.google.com/edu/python/lists)

Place the implementation in src/core/high_scores.py
test_file:
import pytest
import sys
sys.path.insert(0, 'src')
from core.high_scores import *

# These tests are auto-generated with test data from:
# https://github.com/exercism/problem-specifications/tree/main/exercises/high-scores/canonical-data.json
# File last updated on 2023-07-19

import unittest

from high_scores import (
HighScores,
)



def test_list_of_scores(self):
    scores = [30, 50, 20, 70]
    expected = [30, 50, 20, 70]
    assert HighScores(scores).scores == expected

def test_latest_score(self):
    scores = [100, 0, 90, 30]
    expected = 30
    assert HighScores(scores).latest() == expected

def test_personal_best(self):
    scores = [40, 100, 70]
    expected = 100
    assert HighScores(scores).personal_best() == expected

def test_personal_top_three_from_a_list_of_scores(self):
    scores = [10, 30, 90, 30, 100, 20, 10, 0, 30, 40, 40, 70, 70]
    expected = [100, 90, 70]
    assert HighScores(scores).personal_top_three() == expected

def test_personal_top_highest_to_lowest(self):
    scores = [20, 10, 30]
    expected = [30, 20, 10]
    assert HighScores(scores).personal_top_three() == expected

def test_personal_top_when_there_is_a_tie(self):
    scores = [40, 20, 40, 30]
    expected = [40, 40, 30]
    assert HighScores(scores).personal_top_three() == expected

def test_personal_top_when_there_are_less_than_3(self):
    scores = [30, 70]
    expected = [70, 30]
    assert HighScores(scores).personal_top_three() == expected

def test_personal_top_when_there_is_only_one(self):
    scores = [40]
    expected = [40]
    assert HighScores(scores).personal_top_three() == expected

def test_latest_score_after_personal_top_scores(self):
    scores = [70, 50, 20, 30]
    expected = 30
    highscores = HighScores(scores)
    highscores.personal_top_three()
    assert highscores.latest() == expected

def test_scores_after_personal_top_scores(self):
    scores = [30, 50, 20, 70]
    expected = [30, 50, 20, 70]
    highscores = HighScores(scores)
    highscores.personal_top_three()
    assert highscores.scores == expected

def test_latest_score_after_personal_best(self):
    scores = [20, 70, 15, 25, 30]
    expected = 30
    highscores = HighScores(scores)
    highscores.personal_best()
    assert highscores.latest() == expected

def test_scores_after_personal_best(self):
    scores = [20, 70, 15, 25, 30]
    expected = [20, 70, 15, 25, 30]
    highscores = HighScores(scores)
    highscores.personal_best()
    assert highscores.scores == expected
